Reporting Guidelines

Source: vignettes/4_Guidelines.Rmd
4_Guidelines.Rmd

These guidelines can be referred to by citing the package:

  • Makowski, D. (2019). Understand and Describe Bayesian Models and Posterior Distributions using BayestestR. Available from https://github.com/easystats/bayestestR. DOI:10.5281/zenodo.2556486.

Reporting Guidelines

Based on the previous comparison of point-estimates and indices of effect existence, we can conclude that:

  • For simple models and normally distributed posteriors, the MAP estimate seems to be more biased than the mean and the median of the posterior distribution.
  • Aside from being more robust, the median makes more sense than the mean in a probabilistic framework (e.g., there is 50% chance that the true effect is either higher or lower than the median).
  • The traditional ROPE (using a 90% HDI) is not sensitive to delineate highly “significant” effects. The full ROPE (100% HDI) does not present the same flaw.
  • The Probability of Direction (pd) is the closest index to the frequentist p value.

Thus, to minimally describe the posterior distribution of a parameter, we suggest reporting the median and the 90% CI for parameter characterisation and, in the context of null-hypothesis testing, the Probability of Direction (pd) for effect existence and, especially in the context of confirmatory analyses, the ROPE (full) with an explicitly specified range for effect significance.

Interpretation Rules of Thumb

The following thresholds are presented as landmarks only, for comparison with the frequentist framework. Please consider with caution.

  • Probability of Direction (pd)

    • pd < 95% ~ p > .1: uncertain
    • pd > 95% ~ p < .1: possibly existing
    • pd > 97.5% ~ p < .05: likely existing
    • pd > 99% ~ p < .01: probably existing
    • pd > 99.9% ~ p < .001: certainly existing
    • pd = 100%: definitely existing

  • ROPE (full): Extra caution is required as tts interpretation highly depends on other parameters such as sample size and ROPE bounds.

    • < 5% in ROPE: possibly significant
    • < 1% in ROPE: likely significant
    • 0% in ROPE: definitely significant

Note: If you have any advice, opinion or such, we encourage you to let us know by opening an discussion thread or making a pull request.

Template Sentence

Based on these suggestions, a template sentence for minimal reporting of a parameter based on its posterior distribution could be:

  • “the effect of X has a probability of pd of being negative (Median = median, 90% CI […, …], ROPE% in ROPE).”
